description: From Middle English espousen, borrowed from Old French espouser, from Latin spōnsāre, present active infinitive of spōnsō (frequentative of spondeō), from Proto-Indo-European *spend-.

verbs.description: espouse (third-person singular simple present espouses, present participle espousing, simple past and past participle espoused)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To accept, support, or take on as one’s own (an idea or a cause).
examples: Although Dowty’s proposal is attractive from the point of view of the alternative argument linking theory that I am espousing, since it eschews the use of thematic roles and thematic role hierarchies, […], but it still has some drawbacks.
